facts.text: Petition No. 2 of 1960 filed under Article 32 of the Constitution for enforcement of Fundamental Rights.

anchor.surface_text: ORIGINAL JURISDICTION Petition No. 2 of 1960. Petition under Article 32 of the Constitution of India for the enforcement of Fundamental Rights.

facts.text: Judgment delivered on April 28, 1960 by SHAH, J.

anchor.surface_text: 1960. April 28. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by SHAH, J.-The petitioners pray for a writ quashing a scheme approved under s. 68D

facts.text: Petitioners are operators of stage carriages on certain routes in Anekal area, Bangalore District.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioners are operators of Stage carriages on certain routes in the sector popularly known as Anekal area in the Bangalore District.

facts.text: On January 13, 1959, General Manager, Mysore Government Road Transport Department published a scheme under s. 68C for exclusion of private operators on certain routes in Anekal area.

anchor.surface_text: On January 13, 1959, the General Manager, Mysore Government Road Transport Department, who will hereinafter be referred to as the 2nd respondent, pub- lished a scheme in exercise of the powers conferred by s. 68C of the Motor Vehicles Act, 1939, for the exclusion of private operators on certain routes and reservation of those routes for the State transport undertaking in the Anekal area.

facts.text: Chief Minister of Mysore State approved the scheme after considering written objections and oral representations.

anchor.surface_text: The Chief Minister of the Mysore State gave the operators affected by the scheme an opportunity of making oral representations and on perusing the written objections and considering the oral representations, approved the scheme as framed by the 2nd respondent.

facts.text: On April 23, 1959, the scheme was published in the Mysore State Government gazette.

anchor.surface_text: On April 23, 1959, the scheme was published in the Mysore State Government gazette

facts.text: On June 23, 1959, renewal applications by petitioners 1 to 3 for permits were rejected by the Transport Authority.

anchor.surface_text: On June 23, 1959, renewal applications submitted by petitioners 1 to 3 for permits to ply Stage carriages on certain routes covered by the scheme were rejected by the Transport Authority

facts.text: On June 24, 1959, 2nd respondent was given permanent permits for plying buses on those routes.

anchor.surface_text: and the 2nd respondent was given permanent permits operative as from June 24, 1959, for plying buses on those routes.

facts.text: In Writ Petition No. 463 of 1959, High Court of Mysore held that issue of permits to 2nd respondent before expiry of six weeks from application date was illegal.

anchor.surface_text: In Writ Petition No. 463 of 1959 challenging the validity of the permanent permits granted to the 2nd respondent, the High Court of Mysore held that the issue of permits to the 2nd respondent before the expiry of six weeks from the date Of the application was illegal.

facts.text: Renewal permits operative till March 31, 1961 issued to petitioners 1 to 3 and other operators by third respondent.

anchor.surface_text: To petitioners 1 to 3 and certain other operators renewal permits operative till March 31, 1961, were thereafter issued by the third respondent.

facts.text: 2nd respondent applied for fresh permits pursuant to scheme approved on April 15, 1959.

anchor.surface_text: The 2nd respondent applied for fresh permits in pursuance of the scheme approved on April 15, 1959, for plying Stage carriages on routes specified in the scheme

facts.text: Notices returnable on January 5, 1960 served upon affected operators.

anchor.surface_text: and notices thereof returnable on January 5, 1960, were served upon the operators likely to be affected thereby.

facts.text: On January 4, 1960, five petitioners applied to Supreme Court under Art. 32 for quashing the scheme.

anchor.surface_text: On January 4, 1960, the five petitioners applied to this court under Art. 32 of the Constitution for quashing the scheme and for incidental reliefs.

facts.text: Scheme covers fourteen out of thirty one routes in Anekal area.

anchor.surface_text: In the Anekal area, there are thirty-one routes, which are served by stage carriages operated by private operators, and by the approval of the scheme, only fourteen of those routes are covered by the scheme

facts.text: Statement 1 to scheme sets out fourteen routes with details.

anchor.surface_text: Statement 1 sets out the description of fourteen routes with their intermediate points, route length, number of buses to be operated and the maximum number of trips to be performed on each route.

facts.text: Statement 2 lists fifty-six operators with routes and vehicles.

anchor.surface_text: Statement 2 sets out the names and places of business of fifty-six operators together with the routes operated and the numbers of the stage carriages and trips made by those operators.

facts.text: Petitioners claim two operators Chikkaveerappa and Krishna Rao left out from exclusion on notified routes.

anchor.surface_text: It is averred in para. 13 of the petition that two persons, Chikkaveerappa operating on route Chikkathirupathi to Bangalore via Surjapur, Domsandra and Agara and Krishna Rao operating on route Bangalore to Chik- kathirupathi via Agara and Surjapur are not amongst those who are excluded from operating their vehicles on the notified routes.

facts.text: Affidavit by State and 2nd respondent states the two operators were notified as likely affected.

anchor.surface_text: In the affidavit filed by the State and the second respondent, it is submitted that the plea of the petitioners that the two persons operating stage carriages on specified routes were not amongst those to be excluded is incorrect, and that those two persons had been notified by the Secretary of the third respondent that they were likely to be affected on giving effect to the approved scheme.

facts.text: Court finds no evidence that the two operators had right to pick up passengers on notified route.

anchor.surface_text: but the record does not disclose that the two named persons are, in plying their stage carriages, entitled to operate on the route specified with right to stop at the named places for picking up passengers.

facts.text: On October 22, 1959, 3rd respondent rejected applications for permits on one route citing notified area.

anchor.surface_text: Counsel for the petitioners submitted that an order passed on October 22, 1959, by the 3rd respondent the Regional Transport Authority-rejecting applications for permits for one of the fourteen routes to an applicant, indicated that in the opinion of the third, respondent, the scheme related to a notified area and not to notified routes.

facts.text: Chief Minister filed affidavit denying bias and stating he heard objections and gave reasons for approval.

anchor.surface_text: The Chief Minister of the State has filed an affidavit in this case stating that the contention of the petitioners that he was biased in favour of the scheme was baseless he has also stated that he heard such objections and representation as were made before him and he had given the fullest opportunity to the objectors to submit their objections individually.

facts.text: Court holds scheme relates to fourteen notified routes, not to the area.

anchor.surface_text: The scheme must therefore be regarded as one for the fourteen notified routes and not in relation to the area described in column 1.

facts.text: There are five petitioners.

anchor.surface_text: On January 4, 1960, the five petitioners applied to this court

facts.text: Respondents are State of Mysore, General Manager Mysore Government Road Transport Department, Regional Transport Authority Bangalore.

anchor.surface_text: for a writ restraining the respondents, i.e., the State of Mysore, the General Manager, the Mysore Government Road Transport Department and the Regional Transport Authority, Bangalore, from taking action pursuant to the scheme.

facts.text: Intervener is D. R. Karigowda.

anchor.surface_text: K. Daphtary, Solicitor-General of India and B.R.L. Iyengar, for the Intervener  D. R. Karigowda .

holdings.text: The scheme must therefore be regarded as one for the fourteen notified routes and not in relation to the area described in column 1.

anchor.surface_text: The scheme must therefore be regarded as one for the fourteen notified routes and not in relation to the area described in column 1.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Scheme form prescribes area in col1 but exclusion specified in col3 for routes per s68C; no intention to exclude all in area.

holdings.text: the discrimination alleged cannot be deemed to have been made out.

anchor.surface_text: but the record does not disclose that the two named persons are, in plying their stage carriages, entitled to operate on the route specified with right to stop at the named places for picking up passengers.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No evidence two operators had right to pick up on notified routes; notified as affected per affidavit.

holdings.text: Chapter IVA is not merely regulatory of the procedure for carrying on business of road transport by the State it enables the State transport undertaking, subject to the provisions of the scheme, to exclude private operators and to acquire a monopoly, partial or complete, in carrying on transport business, in a notified area or on notified routes.

anchor.surface_text: By Chapter IVA, the State transport undertaking which is either a department of the State or a corporation owned or controlled by the State on the approval of a scheme, is entitled, consistently with the scheme,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Provisions of ss68A-68G empower exclusive permits, cancellation of others, overriding other chapters.

holdings.text: We are therefore of the view that Chapter IVA could competently be enacted by the Parliament under entry No. 21 read with entry No. 35 of the Concurrent List.

anchor.surface_text: We are therefore of the view that Chapter IVA could competently be enacted by the Parliament under entry No. 21 read with entry No. 35 of the Concurrent List.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Entry 21 List III authorizes commercial monopolies; wide amplitude per precedents; not restricted by List II entry 26.

holdings.text: the scheme framed under s. 68C may properly be regarded as law within the meaning of Art. 19(6) made by the State excluding private operators from notified routes or notified areas, and immune from the attack that it infringes the fundamental right guaranteed by Art. 19(1)(g).

anchor.surface_text: In any event, the expression law as, defined in Art. 13(3)(a) includes any ordinance, order, bye-law, rule, regulation, notification custom, etc., and the scheme framed under s. 68C may properly be regarded as law within the meaning of Art. 19(6)

holdings.reasoning_summary: Art13(3)(a) defines law broadly to include orders/notifications; protected by Art19(6).

holdings.text: Section 68D of the Motor Vehicles Act undoubtedly imposes a duty on the State Government to act judicially in considering the objections and in approving or modifying the scheme proposed by the transports undertaking.

anchor.surface_text: Section 68D of the Motor Vehicles Act undoubtedly imposes a duty on the State Government to act judicially in considering the objections and in approving or modifying the scheme proposed by the transports undertaking.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Per precedent Gullapalli; duty from language requiring consideration of objections.

holdings.text: if the Government or the authority to whom the power is delegated acts judicially in approving or modifying the scheme, the approval or modification is not open to challenge on a presumption of bias.

anchor.surface_text: it is also true that the Government on whom the duty to decide the dispute rests, is substantially a party to the dispute but if the Government or the authority to whom the power is delegated acts judicially

holdings.reasoning_summary: Official capacity; no presumption without reliable evidence of bias.

holdings.text: In the absence of any evidence controverting these averments, the plea of bias must fail.

anchor.surface_text: The Chief Minister has given detailed reasons for approving the scheme and has dealt with such of the objections as he says were urged before him. ... In the absence of any evidence controverting these averments, the plea of bias must fail.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Affidavit unchallenged; detailed reasons given; opportunity provided.

holdings.text: we are, on that account, unable to hold that the Chief Minister did not consider those objections.

anchor.surface_text: There is no specific reference in the order to certain objections which were raised in the reply filed by the objectors, but we are, on that account, unable to hold that the Chief Minister did not consider those objections.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Order discusses law/facts; judicial approach evident.

holdings.text: Provided the authority invested with the power to consider the objections gives an opportunity to the objectors to be heard in the matter and deals with the objections in the light of the object intended to be secured by the scheme, the ultimate order passed by that authority is not open to challenge either on the ground that another view may possibly have been taken on the objections or that detailed reasons have not been given for upholding or rejecting the contentions raised by the objectors.

anchor.surface_text: the guarantee conferred by s. 68D ... is guarantee of an opportunity ... judicial approach. But the Legislature does not contemplate an appeal to this Court against the order passed by the State Government approving or modifying the scheme.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s68D guarantees opportunity and judicial approach, not detailed reasons or appeal.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Issue not reached as scheme held for routes.
